The property 'alternating' is defined on functions out of a product V×⋯×VV\times\dots\times VV×⋯×V. If we pick a basis of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn then we get a bijection between Hom(Rn,V)\mathrm{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^n, V)Hom(Rn,V) and V×⋯×VV\times\dots\times VV×⋯×V (where there are nnn copies of VVV). So by translating along this bijection we have a definition of what it means for a function out of Hom(Rn,V)\mathrm{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^n, V)Hom(Rn,V) to be alternating.

The interesting thing about this idea is that it doesn't depend on the basis we chose for Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn. It's not hard to prove that if a map a:Hom(Rn,V)→Wa:\mathrm{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^n, V)\to Wa:Hom(Rn,V)→W is alternating for one choice of basis then it's alternating for every choice of basis. This makes me think that this is a natural way to think about alternating maps.

In fact given a:Hom(Rn,V)→Wa:\mathrm{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^n, V)\to Wa:Hom(Rn,V)→W one can show that the following are equivalent:

  1. For some basis, the corresponding map V×⋯×V→WV\times\dots\times V\to WV×⋯×V→W is alternating.
  2. For every basis, the corresponding map V×⋯×V→WV\times\dots\times V\to WV×⋯×V→W is alternating.
  3. For every basis, the corresponding map V×⋯×V→WV\times\dots\times V\to WV×⋯×V→W is multilinear.

The last of these points shows that the notion of alternating is quite simple from this point of view. It holds because if eie_iei​ and eje_jej​ are two basis elements, then one still has a basis if one replaces eje_jej​ by ej−eie_j-e_iej​−ei​. So we get the alternating property from multilinearity for free.

Other facts about alternating maps also become nice from this perspective. For example, for the usual definition we can say that if a(v0,…,vn−1)a(v_0,\dots,v_{n-1})a(v0​,…,vn−1​) is nonzero then v0,…,vn−1v_0,\dots,v_{n-1}v0​,…,vn−1​ must be linearly independent. From the new point of view this is equivalent to saying that if a(f)a(f)a(f) is nonzero then fff must be injective.

What I'd like to ask is if anyone can see a completely basis independent way of defining 'alternating' from this point of view? I.e. to define what it means to be an alternating map a:Hom(U,V)→Wa:\mathrm{Hom}(U, V)\to Wa:Hom(U,V)→W, without picking a basis of UUU.

One neat application of this would be to apply it when UUU was a non-free module over a ring. Of course one would still need a restriction on UUU corresponding to the fact that nnn must be finite. Presumably UUU would have to be dualizable, a.k.a. finitely-generated projective. One could then use this to give a nice definition of 'determinant' on dualizable UUU, which currently requires the rather ugly method of arbitrarily choosing a U′U'U′ such that U⊕U′U\oplus U'U⊕U′ is free.
What definition of alternating are you using here? Certainly alternating should be more specific than multilinear!

Define the bijection b:Hom(Rn,V)→V×⋯×Vb:\mathrm{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^n, V)\to V\times\dots\times Vb:Hom(Rn,V)→V×⋯×V by f↦(f(e0),…,f(en−1))f\mapsto (f(e_0),\dots,f(e_{n-1}))f↦(f(e0​),…,f(en−1​)) where eee is the standard basis. Then define a:Hom(Rn,V)→Wa:\mathrm{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^n, V)\to Wa:Hom(Rn,V)→W to be alternating if and only if b−1∘ab^{-1}\circ ab−1∘a is alternating.

The meaning of (3) is that if we have that aaa such that b−1∘ab^{-1}\circ ab−1∘a is multilinear, and would also be multilinear no matter which basis we used to define bbb, then aaa is alternating.
Ah, I see the detail I had missed.

If some definition doesn't depend on what basis you pick for Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, then it also works in a basis-independent way for UUU, where UUU is any n-dimensional real vector space.

So, it sounds like you're claiming there's a way to define a "multilinear alternating map" from Hom(U,V)\mathrm{Hom}(U,V)Hom(U,V) to WWW.
Is there a slick way to do this that never brings in a basis? (You bring in the basis and then claim the choice of basis didn't matter.)
Also, are you claiming we need "alternating" here? That is: can we define a "multilinear" map from Hom(U,V)\mathrm{Hom}(U,V)Hom(U,V) to WWW, or only a "multilinear alternating" map?
You can define a multilinear map, but only in a basis dependent way. It's 'alternating' that makes it basis independent.

I'm a bit late to the discussion, but I think you can say that a function a:Hom(U,V)→Wa : \mathrm{Hom}(U, V) \to Wa:Hom(U,V)→W is alternating if for any t∈U⋆t \in U^\start∈U⋆, f∈Hom(U,V)f \in \mathrm{Hom}(U, V)f∈Hom(U,V), the function v↦a(f+vt)v \mapsto a(f + vt)v↦a(f+vt) is affine (i.e. some constant plus a linear function in vvv) and moreover a(f)=0a(f) = 0a(f)=0 for fff non-injective. Basically this is just a restatement of what it means for a function to be multilinear (picking t∈U⋆t \in U^\start∈U⋆ is like picking one of nnn arguments).

Resurrecting this for my own insight into alternating maps. Ordered n-tuples are maps from n. Each has a histogram. Unordered n-tuples are subsets of size n. Each has a characteristic function. The pullback is the injections from n. Symmetric maps are those which factor through the histogram. Alternating maps are those which "factor through the injections".
Requesting a note that this is old hat or has a nicer phrasing.
